Fix double quoting in Windows task execution
body:
VS Code v1.103.0 introduced a regression where task execution on Windows incorrectly adds extra quotes around command lines that are already quoted by extensions, causing task execution to fail.

## The Problem

When extensions create tasks with pre-quoted command lines like:

```typescript
const shellOption: vscode.ShellExecutionOptions = {
    executable: 'cmd.exe',
    shellArgs: ['/C']
};
commandLine = `"${commandLine}"`;  // Extension quotes the command
const task = new vscode.Task(
    { type: 'shell', command: commandLine }, 
    vscode.TaskScope.Workspace,
    title, 
    'extension', 
    new vscode.ShellExecution(commandLine, shellOption)
);
```

VS Code was unconditionally wrapping the command with additional quotes, resulting in:
- **Expected**: `cmd.exe /C "unify_builder -p d:\MyProgram\xxx\builder.params"`
- **Actual**: `cmd.exe /C ""unify_builder -p d:\MyProgram\xxx\builder.params""`

The double quotes cause cmd.exe to fail to parse the command properly.

## The Fix

Added a check in `terminalTaskSystem.ts` to detect if the command line is already quoted before adding quotes:

```typescript
// Before
combinedShellArgs.push('"' + commandLine + '"');

// After  
const isAlreadyQuoted = commandLine.length >= 2 && commandLine.startsWith('"') && commandLine.endsWith('"');
combinedShellArgs.push(isAlreadyQuoted ? commandLine : '"' + commandLine + '"');
```

This ensures that:
- Pre-quoted commands are not double-quoted
- Unquoted commands still receive proper quoting
- Non-Windows shells remain unaffected

## Tests

Added comprehensive unit tests that validate:
- Already quoted commands don't get additional quotes
- Unquoted commands get properly quoted
- Edge cases like partial quotes and empty commands are handled correctly
- Complex scenarios with spaces and special characters work as expected

Fixes #260534.

title: Implement Feature 4: Automatic Generation of tasks.md with Actionable Implementation Plan
body:
This PR implements Feature 4 from the specification: automatic generation of a structured `tasks.md` file from `requirements.md` and `design.md` files, providing teams with actionable and trackable implementation plans.

## Overview

The feature adds a new VS Code command **"Tasks: Generate Tasks from Requirements"** that automatically parses project requirements and design documents to create a comprehensive implementation roadmap.

## Key Components

### TasksGeneratorService
- **Requirements Parsing**: Extracts requirements with priorities, descriptions, and acceptance criteria from markdown files
- **Design Analysis**: Parses technical specifications and architecture details
- **Task Generation**: Creates structured tasks with proper dependency ordering using topological sorting
- **Time Estimation**: Automatically estimates implementation hours based on complexity and acceptance criteria count

### VS Code Integration
- **Command Palette Integration**: Accessible via "Tasks: Generate Tasks from Requirements"
- **Workspace Detection**: Automatically finds requirements.md and design.md in workspace root
- **Sample Generation**: Creates template files for new projects
- **Error Handling**: Comprehensive error handling with user-friendly notifications

## Generated Output Features

The generated `tasks.md` includes:

- **Task List**: Discrete, well-defined implementation tasks with unique IDs
- **Dependency Ordering**: Tasks properly sequenced with clear dependencies (foundation → features → testing)
- **Requirement Linking**: Each task links back to specific requirements with markdown anchors
- **Implementation Details**: Specifies needs for unit tests, integration tests, accessibility, responsiveness, and loading states
- **Progress Tracking**: Multiple checkpoint types and status indicators for each task
- **Visual Dependencies**: Mermaid diagram showing task relationships
- **Summary Statistics**: Total tasks, hours, and priority breakdown

## Example Usage

1. Create `requirements.md` with structured requirements:
```markdown
## User Authentication
**Priority:** high

Users must be able to securely authenticate.

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Users can register with email and password
- Users can log in with valid credentials
```

2. Run "Tasks: Generate Tasks from Requirements" from Command Palette

3. Get comprehensive `tasks.md` with:
```markdown
### 1. Foundation Setup
**ID**: `foundation-setup`
**Estimated Hours**: 6h
**Dependencies**: None

### 2. Implement User Authentication
**ID**: `task-user-authentication`
**Estimated Hours**: 22h
**Dependencies**: foundation-setup
**Related Requirements**: [User Authentication](#user-authentication)
**Implementation Details:**
- Unit Tests: ✅ Required
- Integration Tests: ✅ Required
- Accessibility: ✅ Required
```

## Testing

- Comprehensive unit tests for parsing and generation logic
- Integration tests for VS Code command functionality
- Manual testing with complex requirements scenarios
- Validated output format and dependency ordering

This implementation provides development teams with an automated way to convert project requirements into structured, trackable implementation plans, significantly improving project planning and progress monitoring capabilities.

Fixes #261163.

title: Allow drag and drop for local chat sessions view
body:
This PR implements drag and drop functionality for the `SessionsViewPane` to allow users to drag local chat session items from the Sessions View into the editor to open chat sessions there.

## Implementation

Added a new `ChatSessionsDragAndDrop` class that implements the `ITreeDragAndDrop<IChatSessionItem>` interface with the following key features:

- **`getDragURI()`**: Returns a `ChatSessionUri` for local chat session items only, using `ChatSessionUri.forSession('local', element.id)` as specified in the requirements
- **Type Safety**: Uses proper type guards consistent with the existing `SessionsViewPane.isLocalChatSessionItem()` method to ensure only local sessions (those with `editor`/`group` or `widget`/`sessionType` properties) are draggable
- **Drag-only Behavior**: Implements `onDragOver()` to reject all drop operations, ensuring this is drag-out functionality only
- **User Experience**: Includes optional `getDragLabel()` to show meaningful labels during drag operations

The drag and drop handler is integrated into the tree configuration in `SessionsViewPane.renderBody()` and properly managed through the component lifecycle.

## Example Usage

With this change, users can now:
1. Open the Chat Sessions view
2. Drag any local chat session item (editor-based sessions or chat view widget)
3. Drop it into the editor area to open that chat session

Non-local (remote) chat sessions remain non-draggable to prevent unintended behavior.

Fixes #261275.

title: Add mode separation and improved language ID population for edit telemetry events
body:
This PR addresses GitHub's telemetry requirements by adding mode separation and improving language ID population for edit telemetry events.

## Problem

GitHub's telemetry analysis showed two key issues:
1. No way to differentiate between inline completion edits ('edit' mode) and chat-based edits ('agent' mode) in metrics
2. Language ID was empty ~97% of the time, preventing accurate language-specific reporting

## Solution

### Mode Separation
Added a `mode` field to both telemetry events to distinguish between edit types:
- `editTelemetry.reportInlineEditArc`: Reports `mode: 'edit'` for inline completions
- `editTelemetry.reportEditArc`: Reports `mode: 'agent'` for chat-based edits

### Language ID Fallback
Implemented fallback logic to populate language ID when metadata is empty:
```typescript
// Before: Often empty from metadata
const languageId = data.$$languageId; 

// After: Fallback to document language ID
const documentLanguageId = data.$$languageId || this._document.languageId.get();
```

## Changes Made

1. **Extended telemetry interfaces**: Added `mode` and `documentLanguageId` fields to `EditTelemetryData`
2. **Updated telemetry senders**: Modified both `InlineEditArcTelemetrySender` and `ChatArcTelemetrySender` to:
   - Accept document reference for language ID access
   - Include mode field in telemetry events
   - Use fallback logic for language ID population
3. **Updated instantiation**: Modified telemetry sender creation to pass document reference

## Impact

- **Better Analytics**: GitHub can now separate metrics between 'edit' and 'agent' modes for more precise reporting
- **Improved Data Quality**: Language ID should now be populated in nearly 100% of cases instead of ~3%
- **Backward Compatible**: No breaking changes to existing telemetry structure

Fixes #261225.

title: Explorer view not in sync with folders added to workspace

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

Version: 1.103.0 (Universal)
Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f
Date: 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z
Electron: 37.2.3
ElectronBuildId: 12035395
Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
Node.js: 22.17.0
V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0
OS: Darwin x64 24.6.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add first folder to workspace --> Explorer view shows the folder
2. Add second folder to workspace --> Explorer view doesn't show the folder.
3. Restart VSCode --> Both folders are visible in Explorer view
4. Remove one of the folders --> "Right click on folder" -> "Remove folder from Workspace" --> Explorer view still shows both folders i.e. doesn't refresh.

This started happening from 1.103 version and is very inconvenient, as everytime a new folder is added, VSCode needs to be Quit i.e. Cmd+Q (On Mac) and then reopened.

Request you to please address this issue. 

Thanks in advance.

title: "I'm GitHub Copilot." at the beginning of Copilot Chat answers is superfluous
body: Type: Bug Every answer to my prompts in GitHub Copilot Chat in VSCode starts with "I'm GitHub Copilot." followed by two newlines. This takes up both screen space and mental space when working on code. This appeared following the latest update which introduced GPT-5. Please remove this new feature or at least give the option to Thank you Extension version: 0.30.0 VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (Universal) (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z) OS version: Darwin arm64 23.5.0 Modes:

title: Accessibility Issue: "Tokenization is skipped..."

labels.name: editor-core
labels.description: Editor basic functionality

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: This annoying popup is always where your mouse is, so you can't select text unless you're faster than the animation delay - it's an accessibility issue. No popup should ever block your mouse and vision so you can't see what you are pointing at. This is widely reported as annoying by users, but the solution given is always to enable tokenization. However, in huge log files I don't want to index all that, it will slow down everything. So it's not a good solution. Sometimes I don't want to enable tokenization _and_ I still don't want annoying popups. One solution would be an option to disable such warnings, or move them out of the way.

title: 🚨 GitHub Copilot Extension Caused Irreversible File Loss and Phantom Restorations
body:
I am reporting a critical breach of reliability and trust involving the GitHub Copilot extension. Overnight, multiple .go files in my local project were:
- Blanked out—contents erased without warning
- Deleted entirely—no trace in file history
- Replaced by previously deleted folders—restored with full integrity
This occurred without Git versioning, and the only active tool was GitHub Copilot. The project was built organically through Copilot Chat, which now appears to have been a fragile dependency. Once the chat context was lost, the files it had helped generate were destabilized or wiped.

💸 Billing and Trust Violation
As a paying subscriber, I trusted GitHub Copilot to assist—not sabotage—my development. Instead, it:
- Undermined months of progress
- Restored deleted content without consent
- Erased original work with no recovery path
- Created unfair billing conditions, charging for a tool that actively compromised my project
This is not a minor bug. It’s a violation of developer trust, and it raises serious questions about Copilot’s file handling, session persistence, and ethical safeguards.

🧠 Technical Observations
- TypeScript and JavaScript files remained intact
- Go files were most affected—possibly due to Copilot’s handling of newer language contexts
- Deleted folders reappeared with full content, suggesting internal caching or session replay
- No Git history was available, as the project was local-only

🛠️ Request for Action
I urge GitHub to:
- Investigate Copilot’s file restoration and deletion logic, especially in local-only environments
- Clarify billing policies when the tool causes data loss
- Provide recovery tools or logs for affected users
- Acknowledge the emotional and professional impact of this breach
This isn’t just about code—it’s about the trust we place in tools that claim to assist us. Copilot failed that trust, and I’m asking for accountability.

title: VS Code AI Analytics: Simplified Feedback & Feature Priorities
body:
## TL;DR Summary
People want AI analytics in VS Code to be useful, not a noisy Excel wannabe. The big themes: keep it simple, show real impact (especially for teams), focus on quality over quantity, and don’t make anyone feel like a cheater for using AI.

## Top Features (in Priority Order)
- **Team & Org View:** Let leads see how AI helps their group, with proper permissions.
- **Simple Personal Metrics:** Start with 3–4 clear numbers (Suggestions Shown, Accepted %, Ignored %, Deleted After Accept %). Drill down only if you care.
- **Quality Funnel:** Track what AI suggested, what you accepted, modified, ignored, or deleted after accepting.
- **Friction & Iteration:** Count how many times you hit “continue” and average steps per solved task.
- **Model Breakdown & Cost:** Show which model’s code you actually keep, plus rough cost buckets.
- **Multi-Window Accuracy:** Merge sessions across windows, with a confidence note if data might be partial.
- **API/Extension Hook:** Simple read-only API for personal metrics (team later).
- **Positive Language:** Use “AI assisted” instead of “AI wrote X%”—no shame, just signal.

## Quick Wins
- Add Deleted After Accept.
- Add Continue Count.
- Distinguish Ignored (timed out) vs Rejected (explicitly dismissed).
- Show Model Keep %.

If you want to build trust and avoid dashboard fatigue, start here. Don’t overcomplicate—nobody asked for a performance scoreboard.

---
Feedback source: Twitter thread (Aug 11–12, 2025).

title: Fix background terminals not showing auto approve indicator
body:
Background terminals were not displaying auto-approval rule information, unlike foreground terminals which properly show which rule was used for auto-approval.

## Problem
When terminal commands run in background mode (`isBackground: true`), users couldn't see which auto-approval rule allowed the command to run automatically. This inconsistency made it harder for users to understand why certain background commands were approved without confirmation.

In the provided screenshot, the "npm test" command runs in the background but doesn't show the auto-approval indicator that would normally appear for foreground commands.

## Solution
The issue was in `runInTerminalTool.ts` where the `invoke()` method had two execution paths:
- **Background execution**: Missing logic to include `autoApproveInfo` in the result
- **Foreground execution**: Correctly includes `autoApproveInfo` in the result

The `autoApproveInfo` was properly calculated in the `prepare()` method for both cases, but only the foreground path used it in the final result.

## Changes
- Added the missing auto-approval info logic to the background execution path in `runInTerminalTool.ts`
- The fix extracts `autoApproveInfo` from `toolSpecificData` and sets it as `toolResultMessage` in the returned result
- Added a comprehensive test case to verify the fix works for background commands

## Result
Background terminals now show the same auto-approval indicator as foreground terminals (e.g., "_Auto approved by rule [`npm`](settings)_"), improving user awareness of why commands were automatically approved.

Fixes #261223.

title: Fix hover widget height calculation to prevent layout issues with shell integration diagnostics
body:
The hover widget's `adjustHoverMaxHeight` method could calculate negative or extremely small height values when `forcePosition` is enabled and the target element is positioned near window edges. This caused layout breakage where the StatusBar would disappear when hovering over shell integration diagnostics details.

## Root Cause

When `forcePosition` is true, the method restricts the hover's maximum height based on available space:

```typescript
if (this._hoverPosition === HoverPosition.BELOW) {
    maxHeight = Math.min(maxHeight, this._targetWindow.innerHeight - target.bottom - padding);
} else if (this._hoverPosition === HoverPosition.ABOVE) {
    maxHeight = Math.min(maxHeight, target.top - padding);
}
```

For elements positioned near the bottom of the window (like shell integration diagnostics in the status bar area), `target.bottom` could be close to `window.innerHeight`, resulting in very small or negative `maxHeight` values. This caused invalid CSS `max-height` properties that broke the page layout.

## Solution

Added a minimum height constraint to ensure the hover always has a reasonable size:

```typescript
// Ensure maxHeight is never below a reasonable minimum to prevent layout issues
maxHeight = Math.max(maxHeight, Constants.MinHoverHeight);
```

The 50px minimum is conservative but sufficient for basic hover content, and follows the pattern used by other VS Code hover widgets which use minimums of 250-266px.

## Testing

- ✅ Normal hovers continue to work as expected
- ✅ Shell integration diagnostics hovers no longer break layout  
- ✅ Edge cases with very small available space are handled gracefully
- ✅ No regression in existing hover functionality

Fixes #261067.

title: Lots of notebook related tools/instructions are included in Agent requests even when all notebook tools are unticked
Fix auto-approval for commands with file redirection operators
body:
Commands with file redirection (like `echo "content" > file.txt`) were not being auto-approved even when the base command was in the allow list. This happened because the current logic splits commands on redirection operators and requires ALL sub-commands to be approved individually, treating file paths as separate commands that need their own approval rules.

## Problem

When a user has `"echo": true` in their auto-approve settings and runs:
```bash
echo "Hello, this is some random text content for file1!" > ~/Desktop/test_folder/file1.txt
```

The command gets split into:
1. `echo "Hello, this is some random text content for file1!"` (approved ✅)
2. `~/Desktop/test_folder/file1.txt` (no approval rule ❌)

Since not all sub-commands are approved, the entire command requires manual approval, even though the user only intended to approve the `echo` command itself.

## Solution

Modified the auto-approval logic to recognize and filter out file redirection targets before checking approvals. The fix:

1. **Identifies redirection patterns** for different shells (bash/zsh: `>`, `>>`, `<`, `2>`, `&>`, etc.; PowerShell: `*>`, numbered streams)
2. **Filters redirection targets** from the approval check while preserving all other logic
3. **Maintains existing behavior** for pipes between commands (both commands still need approval)

## Changes

- Added `filterRedirectionTargets()` function to identify and exclude file redirection targets
- Added shell-specific redirection pattern detection for POSIX shells and PowerShell
- Enhanced logging to indicate when redirection targets are excluded
- Added comprehensive tests covering the specific issue case and edge cases

## Testing

The fix resolves the original issue while maintaining existing functionality:
- ✅ `echo "content" > file.txt` auto-approves when `echo` is allowed
- ✅ `ls | grep test` still requires both `ls` AND `grep` to be approved  
- ✅ `rm file.txt > /dev/null` still blocks when `rm` is not approved
- ✅ Supports all major redirection operators across bash, zsh, and PowerShell

Fixes #258658.

title: Enable settings UI for terminal auto approve instead of forcing JSON editing
body:
The terminal auto approve setting (`chat.tools.terminal.autoApprove`) was forcing users to edit settings.json directly instead of providing a user-friendly settings UI. This occurred because the setting's complex schema with mixed value types was not recognized as renderable by the settings editor.

![Terminal auto approve setting showing "Edit in settings.json"](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2cdae129-71c8-46cd-9994-4b64092c82b4)

## Root Cause

The setting uses `additionalProperties` with `anyOf` containing:
- Simple boolean values (`true`/`false`) 
- Complex objects with `approve` and optional `matchCommandLine` properties
- `null` values for unsetting defaults

The existing schema classification logic in `getObjectRenderableSchemaType()` returned `false` for any schema containing non-simple types, causing the setting to be classified as `ComplexObject` and forcing JSON editing.

## Solution

**Extended Object Widget Support:**
- Added `IObjectComplexData` type to support complex object values alongside existing simple types
- Enhanced `ObjectSettingDropdownWidget` to render complex objects with specialized UI controls
- Added dedicated widget for terminal auto approve objects with dropdown for `approve` and checkbox for `matchCommandLine`

**Improved Schema Classification:**
- Modified `getObjectRenderableSchemaType()` to handle `null` types as renderable
- Added special case detection for terminal auto approve pattern (objects with `approve` + optional `matchCommandLine`)
- Updated `getObjectSettingSchemaType()` to properly handle `anyOf` schemas with mixed simple/complex/null types

**Enhanced Display & Editing:**
- Complex values now display in readable format: `{ approve: false, matchCommandLine: true }`
- Users can add/remove patterns and configure complex objects through intuitive UI
- Maintains full backwards compatibility with existing object settings

## Result

The terminal auto approve setting now renders as an editable object widget with:
- Add/remove key-value pairs functionality
- Dropdown/checkbox UI for complex object values
- Inline editing capabilities  
- Proper validation and error handling

Users can now configure terminal auto approve rules through the settings UI instead of manually editing JSON.

Fixes #259670.

title: Add Quick File-Type Filter in Global Search ( e.g, *.ts, *.md ) Without editing "File to Include"
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

**Feature Request:** Quick file-type filter in search

Right now, if I want to search only in certain file types, I have to go to the *Files to include* field and type something like `*.ts` or `*.md` every time.  
It works, but it’s not very fast if you often switch between file types in a big project.

What I think would help:
- A small dropdown next to the search box with common file types (`*.ts`, `*.js`, `*.md`) and maybe a "Custom…" option.
- Or a quick inline shortcut in the search bar, like `:ts` or `:md`, that instantly applies the filter.

Why it would be useful:
- Less typing, faster searches.
- Easier to jump between file types without touching *Files to include*.
- Should be possible as a small UI enhancement without major changes to search logic.

Example:
1. Search: `myFunction` → select `*.ts` → only TypeScript results show up.
2. Search: `docs :md` → only Markdown results show up.

Similar feature exists in JetBrains IDEs, and it’s very convenient. Would love to see something like this in VS Code.

Part of #260880

This is a minimal defensive fix for #260880 where we just disable the message about no shell integration.

Right now telemetry shows similar numbers for no shell integration in the old extension tool and the new core one, so this is the safest approach and we can look into the impact of "the real" fix in Insiders.

title: Inline + On-Demand AI Suggestions
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I would like to request a feature that allows AI suggestions to be shown both:
1. **Inline, on the go** – as I type (already supported in some tools like Copilot).
2. **On demand** – via a new **“Suggest” button** in the UI, which when clicked, would generate AI-powered suggestions **line by line** for the current file or selected code.

**Why this feature is needed:**
While inline suggestions are helpful, sometimes developers want:
- A full overview of suggestions for the entire code block.
- To review line-by-line improvements before applying them.
- More control over when and how suggestions are shown.

**Suggested Functionality:**
- A “Suggest” button in the toolbar or context menu.
- Clicking it sends selected code (or current file) to the AI.
- The response should be:
  - Displayed in a panel or side view.
  - Organized line by line or in a diff-style view.
- Optionally allow applying suggestions individually.

**Benefits:**
- Improves developer control over AI interaction.
- Helps with learning and understanding AI changes.
- Supports more deliberate refactoring sessions.

**Examples / References:**
- Similar to GitHub Copilot’s “Open Copilot” panel, but more line-focused.
- Inspired by tools like CodeWhisperer and ChatGPT.

**Additional Context:**
If you'd like, I’m happy to help prototype or test this feature. Thank you for your awesome work on this project!

<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: `1.103.0` -> `e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f`
- OS Version: `22.04.1-Ubuntu`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. we will generated some files with the agent feature
2. accept them
3. then delete them from inside the vscode, or terminal, or any gui based explorer
4. close the vs code
5. open vscode
6. bam, old deleted files are back

Haven't tested this one more edge case, but it can lead to a huge issue if this issue persists. Let's say I have asked to write me some docs or some code modification from copilot agent, then liked it so, accepted it. Closed vscode and modified the codebase with other ide or agent, which vscode is not aware of, it may override those changes as well. And that will be big problem. As every commit can't be a micro commit, sometimes. So we need to take care of this as well.

Suggested solution:
*Monitor file changes (which ide is already doing), and if agent edited files are edited, if there is a conflict, just accept the user's chanage.*

Willing to working on this one as well.

title: Codespaces localhost or protected MCP connections

labels.name: *question
labels.description: Issue represents a question, should be posted to StackOverflow (VS Code)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0
- OS Version: MacOS Sequoia 15.6

When working with GitHub Codespaces from your local environment (so not the browser based Codespaces editor), VSCode attempts to connect to the Codespaces environment for MCP connections instead of your local machine environment. This causes problems with self hosted MCPs that cannot be added within the Codespaces env (like [the Figma MCP](https://www.figma.com/blog/introducing-figmas-dev-mode-mcp-server/)).

The problem occurs with remote MCP connections (SSE or HTTP) that are behind a VPN for security reasons, as the VPN connection is not being picked up by VSCode, as it still uses the Codespaces environment.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install [the Figma MCP](https://www.figma.com/blog/introducing-figmas-dev-mode-mcp-server/) locally and try to connect to it from a Codespace.

Ideally, when using the desktop version of VSCode + Codespaces, there should either be an option to pick which env to be used for MCP connections (local / Codespaces) and maybe default it to local.

title: Shortcuts inside Quick Open does not work for editor picker. Shortcuts inside editor picker?

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: quick-open
labels.description: Quick-open issues (search, commands)

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

Currently, there is no way to create shortcuts for the editor picker (Quick Open with "edt"), as we can for Quick Open. For example, "workbench.action.alternativeAcceptSelectedQuickOpenItem", which allows us to open in a split editor, does not work for the editor picker, nor does the "inQuickOpen" `when` expression.

It would be great to have these shortcut commands for the editor picker or simply to make Quick Open's commands and `when` clauses work within the editor picker.
